instruction: How were the machine learning models used in the study to classify ore and waste in real-time using hyperspectral remote sensing and deep learning?
Output:
In the study, hyperspectral remote sensing and deep learning (DL) were used to classify ore and waste in real-time. The machine learning models were trained and tested using hyperspectral images of drill core samples from a silver ore deposit. The samples were labeled as either ore or waste material by a site geologist.

The DL model was trained on the labels generated by a spectral angle mapper (SAM) machine learning technique. SAM is a supervised classification algorithm that calculates the spectral similarity between pixels in an image. The DL model learned from the labeled samples to classify new hyperspectral images in real-time.

The performance of the DL model was evaluated using Rand Error and Pixel Error as disagreement analysis and accuracy assessment indices. These metrics measure the disagreement between the predicted classifications and the ground truth labels. The DL model outperformed two other classifiers (supervised DL and SAM, and unsupervised k-means clustering) in terms of overall accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score.

The results showed that the DL model had a performance of 0.89, 0.95, 0.89, and 0.91, respectively, on overall accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score.
